sections.heading: Performance by In-Operando Created Li–S Interactions
Yanyan Liu, Miaomiao Han, Qizhong Xiong, Shengbo Zhang, Cuijiao Zhao,
Wanbing Gong, Guozhong Wang, Haimin Zhang,* and Huijun Zhao*
sections.text:
DOI: 10.1002/aenm.201803935
consumes tremendous energy and natural gas (as the hydrogen source), and generates large amount of CO2 emission.[1] In a stark contrast, the production of NH3 via electrocatalytic N2 reduction reaction (NRR) can be done under ambient conditions using water as the hydrogen source, underpinning energy, and environmental sustainability.[1b-d,2] However, a high yield of NH3 via electrocatalytic NRR is extremely challenge as it requires an electrocatalyst with high catalytic activity to efficiently break the stable triple-bonds of N2 and simultaneously suppress the competitive hydrogen evolution reaction (HER).[1e,3] On one hand, to efficiently break N2 triple-bonds, an electrocatalyst needs to possess strong N2 adsorption ability and low activation energy, especially the first proton-coupled electron transfer/H* addition step. On the other hand, to effectively utilize active H* for NRR and concurrently suppress HER, an electrocatalyst needs to possess low activation energy for Volmer
step (H2O + e− → H* + OH−) and high activation energies for Heyrovsky (H2O + H* + e− → H2 + OH−)/Tafel (2H* → H2) steps involved in HER.[4] Enormous efforts have therefore been devoted to explore new catalyst structures that can effectively boost NRR performance while concurrently suppress HER.[5] Various approaches such as alloying,[5a] constructing superhydrophobic surface layer,[5b] and Li+ incorporation[5c] have demonstrated noticeable effectiveness to achieve such objectives.
The Haber-Bosch process can be replaced by the ambient electrocatalytic N2 reduction reaction (NRR) to produce NH3 if suitable electrocatalysts can be developed. However, to develop high performance N2 fixation electrocatalysts, a key issue to be resolved is to achieve efficient hydrogenation of N2 without interference by the thermodynamically favored hydrogen evolution reaction (HER). Herein, in-operando created strong Li–S interactions are reported to empower the S-rich MoS2 nanosheets with superior NRR catalytic activity and HER suppression ability. The Li+ interactions with S-edge sites of MoS2 can effectively suppress hydrogen evolution reaction by reducing H* adsorption free energy from 0.03 to 0.47 eV, facilitate N2 adsorption by increasing N2 adsorption free energy from –0.32 to –0.70 eV and enhance electrocatalytic N2 reduction activity by decreasing the activation energy barrier of the reaction control step (*N2 → *N2H) from 0.84 to 0.42 eV. A NH3 yield rate of 43.4 μg h−1 mg−1 MoS2 with a faradaic efficiency (FE) of 9.81% can be achieved in presence of strong Li–S interactions, more than 8 and 18 times by the same electrocatalyst in the absence of Li–S interactions. This report opens a new way to design and develop catalysts and catalysis systems.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Electrocatalytic reduction of N2 to NH3 under ambient conditions has been considered as a promising alternative to the energy and resource intensive Haber–Bosch process.[1] It is well known that the over century-old Haber–Bosch process still dominates today’s industrial scale NH3 production. Such a process requires high temperature (400–500 °C) and pressure (100–350 atm),
Adv. Energy Mater. 2019, 1803935
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1803935 (2 of 9)
2D MoS2 is a typical HER electrocatalyst.[6] The theoretical and experimental studies have revealed that the S-edge and Mo-edge sites on 2D-MoS2 are HER active sites.[7] Recently, Sun and co-workers have experimentally proven the electrocatalytic activity of 2D-MoS2 toward NRR.[8] They theoretically confirmed that the positively charged Mo atoms (+0.963 [e]) at the edge of MoS2 are favorable for N2 adsorption and capable of activating N2 bonds for hydrogenation. Although the obtained NH3 yield rate ( NH3R , 8.08 × 10−11 mol s−1 cm−2) and faradaic efficiency (FE, 1.17%) at −0.5 V (vs reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE)) from 0.1 m Na2SO4 electrolyte were low, this work demonstrated the feasibility of using a high performance HER electrocatalyst to catalyze NRR for NH3 production. The same group later demonstrated a NH3R of 29.28 µg h−1 mg−1cat. and FE of 8.34% at −0.4 V (vs RHE) from the same electrolyte by creating rich defects in MoS2 nanosheets.[9] The findings of their study are important as it demonstrated that the NRR performance of a typical HER electrocatalyst such as 2D-MoS2 can be significantly improved by structural modifications. Considering their studies were mainly focused on the influence of structural and surface defects on NRR catalytic activity rather than suppressing the concurrently occurred HER, we envisage that the NRR performance in terms of both NH3R and FE could be further improved by introducing HER suppression functionality into a NRR active electrocatalyst.
Herein, we report the in-operando created strong Li–S interactions to empower the S-rich MoS2 nanosheets with superior NRR catalytic activity and HER suppression functionality that can achieve a NH3R of 43.4 µg h−1 mg−1 MoS2 (4.38 × 10−10 mol s−1 cm−2 or 26.8 µg h−1 cm−2) with a FE of 9.81% at −0.2 V (vs RHE) using 0.1 m Li2SO4 electrolyte, which are more than 8 and 18 times of the achieved NH3R (5.35 µg h−1 mg−1 MoS2) and FE (0.53%) using the same electrocatalyst without Li–S interactions. The theoretical calculations reveal that Li+ in the electrolyte can strongly interact with S-edge sites of MoS2 during NRR process. The strong Li–S interactions can significantly change the H* adsorption free energy (ΔGH*) on S-edge and Mo-edge sites from 0.03 to 0.47 eV and 0.09 to −0.72 eV, respectively. The former retards HER process on S-edge sites and later strongly adsorbs H* to effectively suppress Heyrovsky/Tafel process involved in HER. Importantly, the strong Li–S interactions can also lead to the positively charged Mo edge sites with dramatically increased N2 adsorption energy and reduced NRR activation energy.

sections.heading: 2. Results and Discussion
sections.text:
A three-step synthetic method was used to fabricate the thin-layer MoS2 nanosheets coated carbon fiber electrocatalyst (see the Experimental Section and Figure S1 in the Supporting Information). The commercial bacterial cellulose (BC) with rich surface oxygen-containing functional groups and fiber network structure (Figure S2, Supporting Information) was first used as the adsorption regulator to controllably adsorb Mo source. The BC adsorbed Mo6+ was converted into thin-layer MoS2 nanosheets coated on BC (MoS2/BC) via a facile vapor-phase hydrothermal (VPH) method using thiourea generated gaseous H2S as S source.[6a,10] The VPH method employed in this work
ensures the quantitative conversion of the adsorbed Mo6+ into MoS2.[6a,10] The obtained MoS2/BC was then transformed into thin-layer MoS2 nanosheets coated BC converted carbon fibers (BCCF) by a pyrolysis process at 800 °C in N2 (denoted as MoS2/BCCF) and used as the electrocatalyst. The inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectrometry (ICP-AES) analysis confirms that the amount of the adsorbed Mo on BC is 195 µmol, almost identical to the Mo content in the resultant MoS2/BCCF (193 µmol), suggesting that the adsorbed Mo has been completely converted to MoS2. Figure 1a shows the X-ray diffraction (XRD) pattern of the as-synthesized MoS2/ BCCF. The characteristic peaks at 14.3°, 32.7°, 33.5°, 44.0°, 58.1°, 69.1°, and 70.5° can be respectively indexed to (002), (100), (101), (006), (110), (108), and (202) plane of hexagonal MoS2 (JCPDS No. 73-1508).[6a,7b] The diffraction peak at 25.4° corresponds to the (002) plane of graphitic carbon. The resultant MoS2/BCCF maintains the BC fiber structures with interconnected MoS2 nanosheets coated on BCCF (Figure 1b and inset). The transmission electron microscopy (TEM) image (Figure 1c) further confirms the nanosheet structured MoS2. The high-resolution TEM (HR-TEM) images (insets in Figure 1c) show the lattice fringes of 0.65 and 0.27 nm, corresponding to the (002) and (100) planes of hexagonal MoS2, respectively.[7b,11] The energy dispersive X-ray (EDX) spectrum (Figure S3, Supporting Information) reveals a S:Mo molar ratio of 2.3:1, suggesting a S-rich characteristic of the resultant MoS2.[7] The selected-area TEM image and corresponding EDX elemental mapping images (Figure 1d) indicate that both Mo and S are uniformly distributed over the MoS2 nanosheets. The X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) survey spectrum of MoS2/BCCF (Figure S4a, Supporting Information) confirms the existence of Mo (10.8 at%) and S (25.6 at%) with a S to Mo atomic ratio of 2.4:1, consistent with the EDX determined ratio. The peaks at 232.5 and 229.4 eV revealed by the high-resolution Mo 3d XPS spectrum of MoS2/BCCF (Figure S4b, Supporting Information) are assignable to the binding energies of Mo 3d3/2 and 3d5/2, respectively.[7a,8] In Mo 3d XPS region, a S 2s peak at the binding energy of 226.5 eV can also be observed.[7a,8] The peaks centered at 162.1 and 163.3 eV displayed in the S 2p XPS spectrum of MoS2/BCCF (Figure S4c, Supporting Information) can be ascribed to the S 2p3/2 and S 2p1/2 in MoS2, respectively.[7a,8] The above characterization results confirm the formation of S-rich MoS2 nanosheets on BCCF.
Recently, Wang and co-workers purposely designed and synthesized a NRR electrocatalyst using poly(N-ethylbenzene-1,2,4,5-tetracarboxylic diimide) (PEBCD) grown on carbon cloth to incorporate Li+.[5c] Their theoretical and experimental studies revealed that Li+ association with oxygen functional groups in PEBCD matrix can retard the HER process and create a larger potential window to enable a highly selective NRR process through an alternative “[O–Li+]·N2–Hx” hydrogenation mode. This inspires us to wonder whether Li–S interactions in MoS2 could affect the NRR performance of MoS2 in a similar way to that of Li–O interactions in PEBCD. The feasibility of utilizing strong Li–S interactions to concurrently suppress the HER activity of MoS2 originated from S- and/or Mo-edge sites, increase the N2 adsorption ability and decrease NRR activation energy was then attempted in this work. Based on the S-rich nature of MoS2/BCCF, we predict that the strong
Adv. Energy Mater. 2019, 1803935
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1803935 (3 of 9)
Li–S interactions could be in-operando formed on the S-edge sites during NRR using Li+ containing electrolyte. Figure 2a shows the linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) curves of MoS2/ BCCF from Ar- and N2-saturated electrolytes (0.1 m Li2SO4 and 0.1 m Na2SO4, pH = 3.0) using a three-electrode electrochemical system in a two-compartment electrochemical cell (Figure S5, Supporting Information). When compared to the Na+ based electrolyte (e.g., Na2SO4), MoS2/BCCF exhibits a lower HER activity but higher NRR activity in 0.1 m Li2SO4 electrolyte. Preliminary experiments were then carried out to confirm the NRR electrocatalytic activity of MoS2/BCCF at a fixed potential of −0.2 V (vs RHE) for 2 h in N2-saturated 0.1 m Li2SO4 and 0.1 m Na2SO4 electrolytes (pH = 3.0). It should be noted that in this work, the obtained NRR products such as NH3 and/or N2H4 were analyzed using the indophenol blue method (Figure S6, Supporting Information) and the Watt and Chrisp method (Figure S7a,b, Supporting Information), respectively.[12] The analysis of the resultant samples confirms the production of NH3 without detectable N2H4 (Figure S7c, Supporting Information). As can be seen from Figure 2b, when N2-saturated 0.1 m Na2SO4 electrolyte was used, MoS2/BCCF shows a poor NRR electrocatalytic performance, achieving a NH3 yield rate (denoted as NH3R ) of 5.35 µg h−1 mg−1 MoS2 and FE of 0.53%. In strong contrast, when N2-saturated 0.1 m Li2SO4 electrolyte was used, 8.1 and 18.5 times increased NH3R (43.4 µg h−1 mg−1 MoS2) and FE (9.81%) can be respectively achieved. The control experiments were carried out to eliminate the environmental interference of the yielded NH3 (Figure S8, Supporting Information). Only ignorable NH3 concentration can be detected when experiments were carried out using N2-saturated 0.1 m Li2SO4 (pH = 3.0) without electrocatalyst (blank) and with electrocatalyst but without applied potential (open-circuit). The detected NH3 concentration is also ignorable using MoS2/BCCF in Arsaturated 0.1 m Li2SO4 (pH = 3.0) at −0.2 V (vs RHE) for 2 h (Ar-saturated solution). These experimental results eliminate any noticeable environmental interference to the yielded NH3. The 1H NMR analysis[9,13] was also carried out to quantitatively confirm the yielded NH3 exclusively resulted from the MoS2/ BCCF catalyzed NRR. The experiments were performed using 14N2 and 15N2 as the feeding gases in 0.1 m Li2SO4 (pH = 3.0) at −0.2 V (vs RHE) over a 2 h NRR period. Figure 2c and Figure S9: Supporting Information show the 1H NMR spectra of the standards and the yielded 14NH4+ and 15NH4+, and the corresponding calibration curves, respectively. The yielded 14NH4+ and 15NH4+ concentration determined by 1H NMR is 2.78 and 2.80 µg mL−1, respectively. The 14NH4+ and 15NH4+ concentrations of 2.84 and 2.85 µg mL−1 for these samples were also obtained from the indophenol blue method. The almost identical 14NH4+ and 15NH4+ concentrations determined by both methods categorically confirm that the yielded NH3 is exclusively resulted from the MoS2/BCCF catalyzed NRR. The above results confirm that the Li+-containing electrolyte can significantly boost the NRR performance of MoS2/BCCF. Considering the only difference between the two cases is the electrolyte employed, it is therefore reasonable to assume that the dramatically enhanced NRR performance is directly associated with Li–S interactions on MoS2. Further experiments were then carried out to confirm whether the Li–S interactions are responsible for the enhanced NRR performance. As shown in Figure S10 in the Supporting Information, the cathodic current

density was rapidly decreased during the initial 60 s of NRR process and gradually reached a steady-state after 5 min, which could be resulted from the suppressed HER activity due to the in-operando formation of Li–S interactions on MoS2. A 7Li isotopic labeled Li2SO4 electrolyte (pH = 3.0) was employed to confirm the formation of Li–S interactions during NRR. Figure 2d shows the 7Li solid-state NMR spectra of MoS2/BCCF after 4 h NRR in 7Li isotopic labeled Li2SO4 electrolyte and standard 7Li sample. Apparently, 7Li can be readily determined from MoS2/BCCF after NRR in 7Li isotopic labeled Li2SO4 electrolyte. Importantly, the chemical shift of 7Li in MoS2/ BCCF (δ = −1.964) is shifted −1.776 when compared to the standard 7Li sample (δ = −0.188) due to strong interactions of electron-donating groups with Li.[14] Based on the compositional structure of MoS2, it is likely that the observed chemical shift is caused by the strong Li–S interactions. experiments were also performed to further confirm the existence of strong Li–S interactions on MoS2. The NRR experiments of MoS2/BCCF were conducted in N2-saturated 0.1 m Li2SO4 (pH = 3.0) (denoted as MoS2/BCCF-Li2SO4) and 0.1 m Na2SO4 (pH = 3.0) (denoted as MoS2/BCCF-Na2SO4) at −0.2 V (vs RHE) for 4 h, respectively. The obtained MoS2/ BCCF-Li2SO4 and MoS2/BCCF-Na2SO4 samples were adequately washed with deionized water and vacuum dried at 50 °C before XPS measurements. For comparison, MoS2/BCCF was directly immersed into 0.1 m Li2SO4 (pH = 3.0) for 12 h, then adequately washed with deionized water and vacuum dried at 50 °C (denoted as MoS2/BCCF-immersion) for XPS measurement. The XPS survey spectra of the as-synthesized and above treated MoS2/BCCF samples reveal C, O, Mo, and S responses without Li (Figure S11, Supporting Information). Interestingly, the high-resolution S 2p XPS spectra reveal that S 2p1/2 and S 2p3/2 peaks of MoS2/BCCF-Li2SO4 and MoS2/ BCCF-immersion samples are respectively shifted ≈0.25 and ≈0.10 eV toward higher binding energies when compared to the as-synthesized MoS2/BCCF and MoS2/BCCF-Na2SO4 samples (Figure 2e). It is likely that such shifted binding energies are associated with Li+ interactions with S in MoS2. In fact, the negatively charged MoS2/BCCF surface at pH = 3.0 (Figure S12, Supporting Information) is favorable for Li–S interactions. As mentioned above, the observed sharp cathodic current decrease during the initial stage of NRR process (Figure S10, Supporting Information) could be caused by the in-operando formation of Li–S interactions on MoS2. We therefore obtained the XPS spectra of MoS2/BCCF samples that are subjected to different NRR times (e.g., 2, 10, 30, and 240 min) according to the observed cathodic current dynamic changes shown in Figure S10 in the Supporting Information. Similarly, XPS survey spectra only show C, O, Mo, and S responses (Figure S13, Supporting Information). Compared to the assynthesized MoS2/BCCF, the shifted peak positions of S 2p1/2 and S 2p3/2 to higher binding energies can be observed from MoS2/BCCF sample after 2 min of NRR (Figure 2f). The MoS2/ BCCF-2 min shifted ≈0.10 eV, while a ≈0.25 eV shift was observed from the sample after 10 min NRR. This suggests that Li–S interactions on MoS2 can be rapidly formed in-operando under the electrochemical conditions within 10 min. To further confirm the strong Li–S interactions on MoS2 are responsible for the enhanced NRR performance, NH3R and FE of MoS2/ BCCF with incorporated Li+ by chemical and in-operando electrochemical methods were obtained from 0.1 m Na2SO4 (Figure S14, Supporting Information). It was found that compared to MoS2/BCCF without incorporated Li+, much higher NH3R and FE can be obtained from MoS2/BCCF samples with Li+ incorporation. The above experimental results categorically confirm that MoS2/BCCF samples with incorporated Li+ possess higher NRR activities toward NH3 production due to the strong Li–S interactions.
The density functional theory (DFT) calculations were performed to identify possible positions of Li–S interactions on MoS2. Similar to the recently reported results,[8,9] we also found that the edge sites of MoS2 is electrocatalytically active for NRR, while the basal plane is inert for the N2 adsorption and activation. Figure S15 in the Supporting Information shows the optimized stable structures of MoS2 edge and Li-incorporated
MoS2 edge. One Li atom can be strongly associated with two S-edge atoms of MoS2, having an interatomic distance of 2.26 Å and a binding energy of −3.29 eV. This confirms that thermodynamically, the strong Li–S interactions can occur on the S-edge sites of MoS2. Further DFT calculations were also performed to confirm whether the Li–S interactions on S-edge sites of MoS2 could suppress HER process (Figure 3a,b and Figure S16: Supporting Information). It reveals that without Li–S interactions on S-edge sites, the hydrogen (H*) adsorption free energies (ΔGH*) of 0.03 and 0.09 eV can be respectively obtained on S-edge and Mo-edge sites (Figure S16, Supporting Information), suggesting S-edge sites are more favorable for HER.[6a,b,8] In strong contrast, with Li–S interactions, the ΔGH* changes dramatically to 0.47 eV on S-edge sites (Figure 3a) and −0.72 eV on Mo-edge sites (Figure 3b). Such Li–S interactions induced changes, on one hand, make the S-edge sites thermodynamically unfavorable for HER, on the other hand, make the produced active H* firmly adsorbed on Mo-edge sites that is unfavorable for HER due to the suppressed H2 formation. These DFT results confirm that the Li–S interactions on S-edge sites of MoS2 can indeed suppress HER process.
The DFT calculations were then performed to confirm whether Li–S interactions on MoS2 could promote electrocatalytic NRR activities. It was reported that the positively charged Mo-edge sites of MoS2 are favorable for N2 adsorption and electrocatalytic NRR.[8] Bader charge analysis was performed.[15] The strong Li–S interactions on S-edge sites of MoS2 result in a Mo atomic charge of +0.970 ǀeǀ, while the charge on each S-edge atom associated with Li increases 0.19 e when compared to S-edge atom without Li–S interactions. Such Li–S interactions induced charge redistributions lead to a change in Gibbs adsorption free energy of N2 (Δ N2G ) on Mo-edge site from −0.32 eV (without Li–S interaction) to −0.70 eV (with Li–S interaction, Table S1, Supporting Information). This means that the Li–S interactions can significantly enhance N2 adsorption on Mo-edge sites, which is experimentally confirmed by the data obtained from the N2 temperature programmed desorption (N2-TPD) measurements (Figure S17, Supporting Information). As the chemisorption of N2 on an electrocatalyst is a prerequisite of NRR process,[16] such Li–S interactions induced strong N2 adsorption on Mo-edge sites could be an important attributor for the enhanced NRR performance.
As shown in Figure 3c, Li–S interactions promote electron transfer between the adsorbed N2 and Mo-edge sites. Each adsorbed N2 gains 0.40 e from Mo-edge sites. Figure S18 (Supporting Information) shows the optimized Li-incorporated MoS2 edge structures corresponding to each step of NRR to form NH3. The calculated Gibbs free energy diagrams corresponding to each reaction step with and without Li–S interactions are given in Figure 3d. For N2 adsorption step, the DFT calculation results show that the NN bond is elongated from 1.12 Å for an isolated N2 molecule to 1.16 Å for the adsorbed N2 on Mo-edge sites with Li–S interactions, whereas the NN bond of the adsorbed N2 on Mo-edge sites without Li–S interactions can only be elongated to 1.13 Å. The significantly elongated NN bond of the adsorbed N2 implies that a low activation energy would be required to realize the first hydrogenation step to form *N2H. In fact, thermodynamically, the formation of *N2H is the potential-determining step of the

© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1803935 (6 of 9)
overall NRR.[3b,8] In this step, the NN bond of *N2H can be further elongated to 1.27 Å at the Li-incorporated MoS2 edge sites, which is lengthier than the elongation achieved at MoS2 edge sites without incorporated Li (1.22 Å). As a result, the calculated energy barrier of 0.42 eV for *N2H formation at the Li-incorporated MoS2 edge sites is much lower than that at the MoS2 edge sites without Li–S interactions (0.84 eV). The calculation results also indicate the further NN bond elongation for *N2H2 and *N2H3 formation steps (Table S1, Supporting Information). Interestingly, the *N2H3 formation step on Mo-edge sites with Li–S interactions is a downhill step, while on Mo-edge sites without Li–S interactions is a uphill step that requires to overcome an energy barrier of 0.47 eV.
The above DFT calculation results confirm that the strong Li–S interactions can occur at S-edge sites of MoS2 and such in operando-induced interactions can effectively suppress HER process, enhance N2 adsorption and activate NN bonds to boost NRR performance. With a clear reaction mechanism in mind, we systematically investigated the NRR performance of MoS2/BCCF in 0.1 m Li2SO4 electrolyte. The optimal pH and concentration of the Li2SO4 electrolyte for NRR were firstly experimentally investigated. As can been seen from Figure S19 (Supporting Information), the highest NH3R and FE can be obtained from a 0.1 m Li2SO4 electrolyte with pH = 3.0, which were employed for all subsequent NRR experiments. Figure 4a shows the dependence of NH3R and FE on the applied potential. The corresponding chronoamperometric curves are shown in Figure S20 (Supporting Information). It can be seen that although the steady-state cathodic current densities are increased with the applied cathodic potentials, a maximal NH3R of 43.4 µg h−1 mg−1 MoS2 (4.38 × 10−10 mol s−1 cm−2 or
26.8 µg h−1 cm−2) and a FE of 9.81% are achieved when −0.2 V (vs RHE) is applied. This is because that higher current densities obtained from higher cathodic potentials consist of a larger portion of cathodic current originated from the competing HER as reflected by lower FE values.[17] The achieved
NH3R and FE by MoS2/BCCF are comparable or superior than those recently reported NRR electrocatalysts in aqueous electrolytes (Table S2, Supporting Information). The stability of MoS2/BCCF for NRR was evaluated using N2-saturated 0.1 m Li2SO4 solution (pH = 3.0) at an applied potential of −0.2 V (vs RHE) over 12 h (Figure 4b). Except the initial cathodic current decay due to the suppressed HER process by the inoperando formed Li–S interactions, the chronoamperometric profile maintains almost unchanged during the entire test period, indicating that MoS2/BCCF is highly stable under NRR conditions. Importantly, both NH3R and FE determined over the testing period keeps unchanged (Figure 4c), further confirming the superior stability of MoS2/BCCF. The superior stability of MoS2/BCCF can also be confirmed by the structural and compositional characterization results of the electrocatalyst after used for 12 h stability test. The characteristics of the XRD pattern, Raman spectrum and TEM image of the used MoS2/BCCF are found to be unchanged when compared to those obtained from the as-synthesized ones (Figure S21, Supporting Information), confirming the structural stability of MoS2/BCCF. The reusability of MoS2/ BCCF was evaluated (Figure 4d) using N2-saturated 0.1 m Li2SO4 (pH = 3.0) under −0.2 V (vs RHE) applied potential with a reaction time of 2 h for each cycle. No noticeable decay for both NH3R and FE can be observed, confirming a superior reusability of MoS2/BCCF.

sections.heading: 3. Conclusion
sections.text: In summary, we have demonstrated a new activation approach by in-operando created strong Li–S interactions to empower the S-rich MoS2 nanosheets with superior NRR catalytic activity and HER suppression functionality. The superior NRR performance is resulted from the strong Li+ interactions with S-edge sites of MoS2 that can effectively suppress HER by decreased ΔGH* on S-edge sites and increased ΔGH* on Mo-edge sites, facilitate N2 adsorption by increasing Δ N2G and enhance NRR electrocatalytic activity by decreasing the activation energy barrier of the reaction control step (*N2 → *N2H). The reported in-operando formation of catalytic active structures via catalyst– electrolyte interactions opens a new way to design and develop catalysts and catalysis systems.

sections.heading: 4. Experimental Section
sections.text:
Fabrication of MoS2/BCCF: The commercial BC pellicles (supplied by Hainan Yeguo Foods Co., Ltd., China) were first cut into rectangle, then frozen in liquid nitrogen, and subsequently freeze-dried in a bulk tray dryer (Scientz-18N, Ningbo xingzhi biotechnology co., Ltd.) at a sublimating temperature of −75 °C and a pressure of 0.01 mbar. A typical synthetic procedure is given in Figure S1 (Supporting Information). The pretreated BC (0.5 g) was added to 300 mL of aqueous solution containing 3.0 mmol of (NH4)6Mo7O24 · 4H2O under stirring for 24 h. The BC sample with adsorbed Mo was collected and rinsed thoroughly with deionized water, freeze-dried, and used as the precursor for VPH reaction to fabricate MoS2/BCCF. In details, 2.284 g thiourea was dissolved into 30 mL of deionized water, and then transferred to a 100 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. The VPH reaction was performed at
220 °C for 18 h using a home-made Teflon holder employed to support BC-adsorbed Mo precursor (1.0 g in the case) with a distance of 2.0 cm above the thiourea solution. After VPH reaction, the obtained product was adequately washed with deionized water and ethanol, then vacuum dried at 50 °C for 6 h. The obtained sample was then thermally treated at 800 °C in N2 atmosphere for 3 h to obtain MoS2/BCCF.
Characterization: XRD patterns of the samples were recorded on a Philips X-Pert Pro X-ray diffractometer with Cu-Kα radiation (Kα = 0.15418 nm) at 40 kV and 40 mA. Raman spectra of the samples were measured on a confocal microscope Raman system (LabRAMHR800, Horiba Jobin Yvon, Japan) using an Ar ion laser operating at 532 nm. The morphologies and structures of the samples were investigated by the field emission scanning electron microscope (FE-SEM, SU8020, Hitachi, Japan) with an acceleration voltage of 5.0 kV and TEM (JEOL-2010, Japan) with an accelerating voltage of 200 kV. The elemental mapping images of the samples were obtained on a JEOL-2010 (Japan) transmission electron microscope. XPS analysis of the samples was performed on an ESCALAB 250 X-ray photoelectron spectrometer (Thermo, America) equipped with Al Kα1, 2 monochromatized radiations at 1486.6 eV X-ray source. The Mo content on BCCF was determined by the ICP-AES (ICP-6300, Thermo Fisher Scientific). N2 temperatureprogrammed desorption (N2-TPD) curves of the samples were measured on a Quantachrome ChemBET Pulsar TPR/TPD. Zeta potential was detected by Zetasizer300Sa Malvern Analyzer.
Electrochemical Measurements: All electrochemical measurements were performed at room temperature using an electrochemical workstation (Zahner, Germany) and a three-electrode electrochemical system in a two-compartment electrochemical cell. A MoS2/BCCF coated carbon cloth working electrode, an Ag/AgCl (saturated KCl electrolyte) reference electrode and a Pt mesh auxiliary electrode were employed. Prior to the NRR experiments, the Nafion membrane (Nafion 117) was first protonated by boiling in deionized water for 30 min, then in H2O2 for 1 h and subsequently in deionized water for another 1 h, followed by 2 h in 0.5 m H2SO4, and finally for 5 h in deionized

water. All pretreatment experiments of the Nafion 117 membrane were performed at 80 °C. The potentials reported in this work were converted to the RHE scale through calibration with the following equation: E (V vs RHE) = E (V vs Ag/AgCl) + 0.197 + 0.059 × pH. The polarization curves of the catalysts were the steady-state ones after several cycles. For the NRR test, the chronoamperometry experiments were conducted in N2saturated 0.1 m Li2SO4 solution (pH = 3.0) (20 mL of electrolyte was first purged with N2 for at least 30 min before the measurement). For the preparation of working electrode, 10 mg catalyst was first dispersed in 1.0 mL of absolute ethanol and 50 µL of Nafion solution (5.0 wt%) under ultrasonication for 5 min to form a homogeneous catalyst ink. After that, the as-prepared catalyst ink was completely loaded onto a commercial carbon cloth substrate with an area of 1.0 × 1.0 cm2 and then dried under ambient conditions for further use.
Determination of Ammonia: The concentration of the produced NH3 during NRR was determined by the indophenol blue method. Typically, 5.0 mL of electrolyte was sampled from the cathodic chamber, and diluted with deionized water to 10 mL. Then 500 µL of 1.0 m NaOH solution containing sodium citrate (5.0 wt%) and salicylic (5.0 wt%) was added to the above 10 mL of sample solution. Subsequently, 100 µL of sodium nitroferricyanide solution (1.0 wt%) and 100 µL of NaClO solution (0.55 m) were added to the above mixture. After standing at room temperature for 1 h, the UV–vis absorption spectrum was measured at a wavelength of 697 nm. The concentration (NH4+-N)absorbance curve used for estimation of NH3 amount was calibrated using standard NH4Cl solution with NH4+-N concentrations of 0.0, 0.2, 0.4, 0.6, 0.8, and 1.0 µg mL−1 in 0.1 m Li2SO4 (pH = 3). The fitting curve (y = 0.958x–0.005, R2 = 0.999) showed good linear relation between the NH4+-N concentration and absorbance.
Determination of Hydrazine: The Watt and Chrisp method was applied to analyze the N2H4 yield in the electrolyte. The p-C9H11NO (5.99 g), HCl (30 mL), and C2H5OH (300 mL) were first mixed as a color reagent. In detail, 1.0 mL of post-NRR electrolyte was acidized with 9.0 mL of 1.0 m HCl solution, and then added 5.0 mL of color reagent with rapid stirring for several times at room temperature. After incubating for 20 min, the mixture was measured on an UV–vis 2700 spectrophotometer with absorbance at a wavelength of 455 nm. The obtained calibration curve was used to calculate the hydrazine concentration.
Calculation of NH3 Yield Rate ( 3RNH ) and FE: The faradaic efficiency for N2 reduction was defined as the amount of electric charge used for synthesizing NH3 divided the total charge passed through the electrodes during the electrolysis. The total amount of NH3 produced was measured using colorimetric methods. Assuming three electrons were needed to produce one NH3 molecule, the FE could be calculated as follows
Faradaic efficiency FE, % (3 )/ 100%NH N3F C V Q( ) = × × ×− (1) The NH3R was calculated using the following equation
( )= × ×−(14 )/NH NH N3 3R C V t S (2)
where F is the faraday constant, −NH N3C is the measured molar concentration of NH4+-N, V is the electrolyte volume, Q is the sum of electric charge recorded by electrochemical workstation, 14 is the molar mass of NH4+-N atom, t is the reaction time, and S is the geometric area of working electrode.
Isotope Labeling Experiments: The 14N and 15N isotopic labeling experiments were conducted using 14N2 and 15N2 as the feeding gases (99% enrichment of 15N in 15N2, supplied by Hefei Ninte Gas Management Co., Ltd.). Prior to use for NRR measurements, 14N2 and 15N2 feeding gases were purged through a 1.0 × 10−3 m H2SO4 solution and water to eliminate the potential NOx and NH3 contaminants.[18] After the electrochemical reaction in 0.1 m Li2SO4 solution (pH = 3.0) at −0.2 V (vs RHE) for 2 h, the reaction solution was concentrated to 2.0 mL at 80 °C. Then, 0.8 mL of above solution mixed with 0.2 mL of D2O was used for 1H NMR spectroscopy measurement (Bruker AVANCE AV III 400). The 1H NMR analysis and the calibration curve construction
were carried out in accordance with the reported method.[18] The 7Li solid-state NMR spectrum was detected by using solid-state nuclear magnetic resonance spectorometer (Bruker AVANCE III 400 WB). Standard 7Li2SO4 sample was purchased from Aladdin and used without further purification. The MoS2/BCCF after NRR of 4 h in 0.1 m Li2SO4 electrolyte (pH = 3.0) at −0.2 V (vs RHE), was adequately washed with deionized water, and then dried at 50 °C in vacuum for 12 h for 7Li isotopic labeling experiment.
Theoretical Calculations: All the calculations have been performed within the framework of DFT, using the Vienna ab initio simulation package (VASP). The electron–electron exchange-correlation interaction was described with Perdew–Burke–Ernzerhof generalized gradient approximation (PBE-GGA) functional. The projector augmented wave (PAW) method has been used to describe the inert core electrons. A cut-off energy of 450 eV was employed for the expansion of the wave functions. The 2H-MoS2 crystal was modeled with the primary unit cell including 2 Mo atoms and 4 S atoms. Since it has been reported that the edge of MoS2 is electrocatalytically active,[8,19] a slab was built using (2 × 1) (−210) surface to simulate the edge. The vacuum thickness was set to 15 Å in all slab calculations. The structures were relaxed until the total energy changes within 1 × 10−4 eV per atom and the Hellmann– Feynman force on each atomic site was less than 0.05 eV Å−1. 2 × 2 × 1 Monkhorst–Pack k-point sampling was used. The van der Waals force was considered throughout.
The Gibbs free energy of the adsorbed species is calculated as following equation
Δ = Δ + Δ − ΔZPEG E E T S (3)
where ΔE is the chemisorption energy change between the reactant and product species adsorbed on catalyst surface obtained directly from DFT calculations, ΔEZPE is the difference in zero point energy, T is the temperature (T = 298.15 K), and ΔS is the entropy difference. For the adsorbed species, only the vibrational frequencies and entropy were considered for the energy correction.

metadata.abstractText: DOI: 10.1002/aenm.201803935 consumes tremendous energy and natural gas (as the hydrogen source), and generates large amount of CO2 emission.[1] In a stark contrast, the production of NH3 via electrocatalytic N2 reduction reaction (NRR) can be done under ambient conditions using water as the hydrogen source, underpinning energy, and environmental sustainability.[1b-d,2] However, a high yield of NH3 via electrocatalytic NRR is extremely challenge as it requires an electrocatalyst with high catalytic activity to efficiently break the stable triple-bonds of N2 and simultaneously suppress the competitive hydrogen evolution reaction (HER).[1e,3] On one hand, to efficiently break N2 triple-bonds, an electrocatalyst needs to possess strong N2 adsorption ability and low activation energy, especially the first proton-coupled electron transfer/H* addition step. On the other hand, to effectively utilize active H* for NRR and concurrently suppress HER, an electrocatalyst needs to possess low activation energy for Volmer step (H2O + e− → H* + OH−) and high activation energies for Heyrovsky (H2O + H* + e− → H2 + OH−)/Tafel (2H* → H2) steps involved in HER.[4] Enormous efforts have therefore been devoted to explore new catalyst structures that can effectively boost NRR performance while concurrently suppress HER.[5] Various approaches such as alloying,[5a] constructing superhydrophobic surface layer,[5b] and Li+ incorporation[5c] have demonstrated noticeable effectiveness to achieve such objectives. The Haber-Bosch process can be replaced by the ambient electrocatalytic N2 reduction reaction (NRR) to produce NH3 if suitable electrocatalysts can be developed. However, to develop high performance N2 fixation electrocatalysts, a key issue to be resolved is to achieve efficient hydrogenation of N2 without interference by the thermodynamically favored hydrogen evolution reaction (HER). Herein, in-operando created strong Li–S interactions are reported to empower the S-rich MoS2 nanosheets with superior NRR catalytic activity and HER suppression ability. The Li+ interactions with S-edge sites of MoS2 can effectively suppress hydrogen evolution reaction by reducing H* adsorption free energy from 0.03 to 0.47 eV, facilitate N2 adsorption by increasing N2 adsorption free energy from –0.32 to –0.70 eV and enhance electrocatalytic N2 reduction activity by decreasing the activation energy barrier of the reaction control step (*N2 → *N2H) from 0.84 to 0.42 eV. A NH3 yield rate of 43.4 μg h−1 mg−1 MoS2 with a faradaic efficiency (FE) of 9.81% can be achieved in presence of strong Li–S interactions, more than 8 and 18 times by the same electrocatalyst in the absence of Li–S interactions. This report opens a new way to design and develop catalysts and catalysis systems.
